result_equations.equation: H(q_i, del S/del q_i, t) + del S/del t = 0

explanation: The Hamilton-Jacobi equation is a reformulation of classical mechanics as a first-order partial differential equation for the action `S(q_i, t)`. It describes the evolution of Hamilton's principal function `S` such that its spatial gradients equal the momenta. Solving the H-J equation yields `S` from which the equations of motion can be obtained, providing a bridge to wave mechanics and ultimately to Schr√∂dinger's equation.

definitions.definition: Hamilton's principal function (action) depending on coordinates `q_i` and time.
Conjugate momentum, given by `p_i = del S/del q_i`.

assumptions.text: There exists a differentiable action function `S(q_i, t)` generating the motion via `p_i = del S/del q_i`.
The solution `S(q,t)` (a complete integral) contains as many arbitrary constants as degrees of freedom, enabling general solutions.
One can perform a canonical transformation generated by `S(q,t)` such that new momenta are constants.
The transformed Hamiltonian vanishes (`K = 0`), so the old Hamiltonian plus time derivative of `S` equals zero.

derivation.description: Define the function `S(q_i, t)` such that its gradient yields the momentum: `p_i = del S/del q_i`. This S will serve as a generating function of a canonical transformation.
Require that the new Hamiltonian is zero. This condition leads to the Hamilton-Jacobi equation: `del S/del t + H(q_i, del S/del q_i, t) = 0`.
derivation.equation: H(q_i, p_i, t) + del S/del t = 0

derivation.description: The H-J equation is a nonlinear PDE for `S(q,t)`. Solving it yields the action from which one can recover trajectories via `p_i = del S/del q_i` and `dot q_i = del H/del p_i`.
